topics.body:
"@Whatevs":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/537ec71b63687212bb010000#post_537ec71b63687212bb010000
While there are several factors that go into birthrates such as level of development of a country(as a country becomes developed their birthrates go down) and tons of other factors the financial stability of couples is still one of these factors.  Since the recession the number of children per couple has been steadily and constantly going down for the simple reason couples can no longer afford having plenty of children; removing tax breaks for married couples would add onto this and further reduce birth rates.  The thing to keep in mind though is that for a country to be economically stable one of the biggest thing is to have a stable or growing population; if a population is in decline that can and will cause large scale economic stagnation.

topics.body:
"@someguy111":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/537ec535636872620d070000#post_537ec535636872620d070000
[bq="someguy111"]"@Whatevs":/dis/the-time-wasting-thread/post/537ec3f46368722c275e0000#post_537ec3f46368722c275e0000
Actually _you_ are the one thinking with feelings; you are basing these "laws" on your own hate/dislike for marriage equality, basically "I don't like them gays so I'm gonna make it so they are treated differently because my personal preference to sexual orientation should interfere with someone's private life." 

I hate smoking, like _really_ hate it. It is a filthy disgusting habit and I with people would stop smoking because I know how bad it can be.

But I would never take away someone's freedom to smoke because it is their life and their body.

Personal preference has no place in lawmaking. [/bq]
All this. I agree fully.
